z:row.TitlePrimary: Energy deposition and shock wave evolution from laser-generated plasma expansions
z:row.Keyword: laser beam effects|plasma collision processes|plasma shock waves|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: One-dimensional radiation-hydrodynamics calculations have been performed to study the structure and evolution of blast waves resulting from laser-generated plasma expansions. The results are compared with experimental data obtained at the Naval Research Laboratory [Laser Interaction and Related Plasma Phenomena (Plenum, New York, 1986), vol.7, p.857-77]. In these calculations, target ions expand into a stationary background gas with an initial pressure ranging from 25 mTorr-5 Torr. Because the stopping ranges of the target ions are comparable to the dimensions of the shock, the blast wave properties are sensitive to the ion stopping cross sections. In some calculations, the effects of radiation transport were neglected in order to assess its importance. The results presented in this paper are in generally good agreement with available experimental data, and indicate that the observed blast wave properties can be accounted for by using a classical collision model to describe the interaction between the target ions and the background plasma
z:row.User2: energy deposition; one-dimensional radiation-hydrodynamics calculations; shock wave evolution; laser-generated plasma expansions; blast waves; Naval Research Laboratory; target ions; stationary background gas; initial pressure; stopping ranges; blast wave properties; ion stopping cross sections; effects of radiation transport; classical collision model; background plasma; 25 mTorr to 5 Torr

z:row.TitlePrimary: RADIOLOGICAL DOSE CALCULATIONS FOR THE DIODE REGION OF THE LIGHT ION FUSION TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY
z:row.Keyword: DOSIMETRY -- Calculations|NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions|STAINLESS STEEL - Radiation Effects|ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS - Radiation Effects|NEUTRONS - Transport Properties
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Biological dose rate calculations have been performed for a point external to the diode vacuum casing of the proposed Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility for times following an operational period of 1 month. The primary diode material considered is Type 304LN stainless steel, with an alternative material of Al-6061-T6. Using a realistic pulse-sequence calculation scheme to account for the pulsed operation mode of the facility, it is shown that for both the stainless steel and aluminum diodes the dose rates external to the diode vacuum casing are greater than 1 rem/h after a 1-day shutdown period. After a 1-week shutdown period, the dose rates have dropped to 90 and 12 mrem/h, respectively.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.Abstract: The authors consider plasma discharge channels for light ion beam transport in the light ion beam fusion reactor study LIBRA. Laser-guided discharges would form these plasma channels in a 3.55×1018 atoms/cm3 helium background gas. They have analyzed the issues of channel formation, ion transport in plasma channels, ion beam power limits imposed by stability and energy loss issues, and the use of applied magnetic fields to inhibit electrical breakdown between the channels and target chamber walls. Based on these analyses, they feel that they have a viable design for plasma channels for LIBRA, though there are still some issues that they have yet to study

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Beam propagation in preformed plasma channels is a possible method for providing the required standoff distance between the ion diodes and the targets in inertial confinement fusion (ICF) facilities. Large electrical discharges, guided by laser preionization, would rarify the channel and form ion-confining azimuthal magnetic fields. A Lagrangian magnetohydrodynamics computer code with multigroup radiation diffusion has been used to study the radial behavior of the channel during formation in different gases, with different discharge-current histories, and with different laser profiles. It is believed that the key to forming the plasma channels that are required for ICF is in keeping the gas temperature low except in the region very near the axis of the channel. It has been found that controlling the radiant heat transfer provides the best channels. These computational results have been related to parameters that are relevant to the LIBRA light-ion-beam fusion reactor conceptual design and the Sandia National Laboratory Target Development Facility conceptual design.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma Channels; Inertial Confinement Fusion; Abstract Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: Target chamber designs for the Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2), 12-16 Oct. 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility (TDF) for testing high-gain inertial confinement fusion targets is discussed. Two designs for the target chamber for the TDF are presented, and the response of the chamber to target explosions is analyzed for each of them. One design is optimized for minimum radioactivity induced in the target chamber while the other is of small size and greater simplicity. It is shown that both designs are feasible, and the advantages of each are discussed
z:row.User2: target chamber design; high-gain inertial confinement fusion targets; target explosions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Design studies of the APEX light ion fusion experiment
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2), 12-16 Oct. 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The APEX project is an upgrade of the PBFA-II light-ion fusion accelerator, to allow pulse shaping for driving high-gain ICF (inertial confinement fusion) targets. This upgrade includes modification of the pulsed power, replacement of the barrel diode with an extraction diode, addition of a z-pinch plasma channel, and addition of a shielded target chamber. The discussion focuses on the structural response of the target chamber to a 100-MJ light-ion-driven target microexplosion, shielding and containment of the induced radioactivity, and modification of the PBFA-II facility to accommodate the APEX chamber
z:row.User2: design; APEX light ion fusion experiment; pulsed power; extraction diode; z-pinch plasma channel; shielded target chamber; structural response; target chamber; light-ion-driven target microexplosion; shielding; PBFA-II facility

z:row.TitlePrimary: DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS FOR THE SIRIUS-M ICF MATERIALS TEST FACILITY
z:row.TitleSecondary: 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering, Proceedings.
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR -- Materials|RADIATION DAMAGE|TOKAMAK DEVICES - Materials|TRITIUM
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: SIRIUS-M is a fusion materials test facility designed to duplicate the time-dependent radiation damage structure unique to inertial confinement fusion (ICF) systems to provide the technology base for an ICF demonstration facility. Single-shell ICF targets with a gain of 13. 4 are symmetrically illuminated by 92 beams of a KrF laser with a total energy of 1 MJ. The impact of tritium breeding and self-sufficiency on the design and economics of SIRIUS-M was examined. The impact of target yield on cavity design and overall costs is examined. It is shown that no economic advantage is gained by using higher yield (100-MJ) targets. Various shielding options were examined to minimize radiation streaming to the laser building through the 92 beam ports. It is shown that this can be achieved using a beam crossover between the last two optical elements.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: SIRIUS-M; FUSION MATERIALS TEST FACILITY; INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION; RADIATION STREAMING; RADIATION SHIELDING

z:row.Abstract: SIRIUS-M is a fusion materials test facility designed to duplicate the time-dependent radiation damage structure unique to ICF systems in order to provide the technology base necessary for an ICF demonstration facility. Single-shell ICF targets are symmetrically illuminated by 32 beams of a KrF laser with a total laser energy of 1 MJ. A wall loading of 2 MW/m2 is achieved at a repetition rate of 10 Hz and target gain of 13.4. Xenon gas at a pressure of 133 Pa (1 torr) is placed in the 2 m radius, graphite-tiled cavity in order to protect the first wall from the X-rays and ions produced by the explosions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radiological dose calculations for the chamber and diode region of the Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Engineering Proceedings. 12th Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.87CH2507-2), 12-16 Oct. 1987

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Biological dose rate calculations are presented for two preliminary designs of the Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility (TDF) for times following an operational period of one month. The primary wall material considered is aluminium AL-6061-T6, with an alternative material being 2-1/4 Cr-1 Mo steel. The diode material considered is SS304LN stainless steel and the penetration in the chamber wall is 10 cm in radius. As an alternative to the base-case 3-m-radius chamber design, a 1-m-radius chamber is analyzed with various shield materials-borated water, concrete and graphite-between the chamber wall and the diode. For the diode region calculation, the first wall is taken as Al-6061-T6 for both the 1-m and 3-m cases
z:row.User2: biological dose rates; chamber; diode region; Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility; dose rate; primary wall material; diode material; shield materials; borated water; concrete; graphite; 3 m; 1 m; H3BO3; C

z:row.Abstract: To ensure that safety-related equipment remains operational in adverse environments, one must consider certain operational transients in order to qualify this equipment. In this study, the authors investigate the effects associated with a high-energy line break within the auxiliary building of a pressurized water reactor (PWR). They specifically focus on the Kewaunee PWR for this analysis, since it has possible ramifications for equipment qualification in the auxiliary building

z:row.TitlePrimary: STEAM GENERATOR MODEL FOR A TWO-LOOP PRESSURIZED WATER REACTOR
z:row.TitleSecondary: Heat Transfer - Pittsburgh 1987.
z:row.Keyword: STEAM GENERATORS -- Mathematical Models|NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS|HEAT TRANSFER
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In any attempt to accurately simulate a pressurized water reactor nuclear power plant, a model for the steam generator must be included. This paper presents a theoretical and computer model based on first principles for a vertical U-tube, natural circulation steam generator. The Kewaunee nuclear station's Westinghouse steam generators serve as the basis for the geometric and operating parameters of this model. The model has been compared to a series of standard transient tests and comparing the results with previous RETRAN analysis of the same transients. These tests include a 50% load reduction from 100% power, and a reactor trip from 100% power. The development of the model, the test results, the computer code itself, a users' manual for the computer code, and suggestions for improving the model's performance have been included.

z:row.User2: TWO-LOOP PRESSURIZED WATER REACTOR

z:row.TitlePrimary: Surry severe-accident containment load calculations using HMC
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1986 Winter Meeting of the American Nuclear Society, 16-20 Nov. 1986
z:row.Keyword: fission reactor cooling and heat recovery|fission reactor safety|fission reactor theory and design
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In a nuclear reactor, the containment represents the final barrier to fission product release following a severe accident. The timing and manner of containment loading are important in determining if a failure occurs and the magnitude of radioactivity release. A variety of computer models have been developed to analyze severe accidents and in particular the containment. Recently, physical processes are of interest involving fuel/coolant interactions, hydrogen combustion, and direct heating following reactor pressure vessel (RPV) breach with containment feedback. Based on this need the HMC code was developed. The authors discuss scoping calculations using HMC to investigate containment loads for the Surry reactor under a variety of parametric boundary and initial conditions (low and high RPV pressures) at the time of vessel breach
z:row.User2: severe-accident containment load calculations; HMC; fission product release; pressure vessel; breach; containment feedback; scoping calculations; Surry reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: Activation studies of the Light Ion Beam Target Development Facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: Second International Conference on Fusion Reactor Materials (ICFRM-2), 13-17 April 1986
z:row.Keyword: alloy steel|aluminium alloys|dosimetry|fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|graphite|magnesium alloys|moderators|radiation protection|silicon alloys|titanium compounds
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Biological dose calculations have been performed for the target chamber of the Target Development Facility (TDF). Placement of a neutron moderator structure in the interior of the target chamber for the moderation of the high energy neutrons has been investigated as a viable option for lowering the biological dose rates of the chamber wall materials, Al 6061-T6 and 21/4Cr-1Mo steel. Two moderator materials are considered, one made of H-451 graphite and the other of titanium hydride. In particular, a 40% porosity, 1 m thick graphite structure within the aluminum wall reduces the dose rate at the chamber wall outer surface to 13.1 mrem/h at 1 week after shutdown as compared to 1.29 rem/h without the moderator. A suitable maintenance schedule based on the 40% porosity graphite moderator design and on the allowable average dose of 1.25 rem per quarter is presented
z:row.User2: Cr-Mo steel; Light Ion Beam Target Development Facility; target chamber; neutron moderator structure; high energy neutrons; biological dose rates; chamber wall materials; moderator materials; porosity; shutdown; maintenance schedule; graphite moderator design; TiH; Al-Mg-Si; FeCrMoC

z:row.TitlePrimary: Graphite first wall thermal performance in ICF reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Second International Conference on Fusion Reactor Materials (ICFRM-2), 13-17 April 1986
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|graphite|ion beam effects|laser beam effects|X-ray effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Graphite has been considered as a candidate material for the first wall in ICF reactors. The authors show the thermal performance of the graphite first wall (GFW) in the 0.25 μm laser driven materials test reactor SIRIUS-M. The first wall temperature response due to the X-rays, reflected laser light, and ions that emanate from the 13.4 MJ yield target was calculated for dry GFWs which were either unprotected or gas protected. Evaporation rates and thermal stresses were calculated and minimum radii were chosen for both cases. It was found that the reflected laser light from the target produces the highest temperature rise in the gas protected GFW. If 10% of the laser light is reflected from the target and the reflectivity of graphite is 50%, the maximum thermal stress in the GFW is about 90% of the compressive strength for a 2 m radius cavity. Therefore, the viability of the first wall design depends critically on the laser light reflected from the target, the graphite reflectivity and the strength of the graphite
z:row.User2: fusion reactor materials; first wall thermal performance; ICF reactor; candidate material; graphite first wall; SIRIUS-M; first wall temperature response; X-rays; reflected laser light; ions; thermal stresses; compressive strength; graphite reflectivity; C

z:row.TitlePrimary: Preconceptual design of the light ion beam fusion target development facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: 11th Symposium on Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.CH2251-7), 18-22 Nov. 1985
z:row.TitleTertiary: 11th Symposium on Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.CH2251-7)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The light-ion fusion target development facility (TDF) will be built in the 1990s, following the anticipated successful operation of PBFA-II, a pulsed power driver system that is expected to drive ICF targets to breakeven conditions. The TDF will be used to test high-yield targets driven by light ion beams. The TDF is the first light ion facility that must be designed to withstand the environment created by high-yield targets. A target chamber with a fatigue lifetime of 15000 shots at 200 MJ and 200 additional shots at 800 MJ using conservative ASME guidelines has been designed. Alternative design features to reduce the induced radioactivity in the chamber are discussed
z:row.User2: light ion beam fusion target development facility; breakeven; high-yield targets; induced radioactivity; 200 MJ; 800 MJ

z:row.TitlePrimary: Numerical simulation of an ICE target explosion in a stratified gas atmosphere
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1986 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 15-19 June 1986
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Two-dimensional radiation hydrodynamics simulations of a light-ion fusion target-generated microfireball in a stratified N2/He gas atmosphere have been performed. Target microexplosions of 200 and 800 MJ were investigated. The intent of this configuration was to determine if the stratified gas (with different opacities) could be used to reduce the overpressure on the diodes placed at the walls of the target chamber and also the diagnostic equipment placed below the target explosion position in the nitrogen layer. Nonspherical fireball propagation caused by `venting' of the fireball once its radiation front reached the N2/He interface was investigated. The interface is within the distance from the target where the fireball shock breaks away from the radiation diffusion wave

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma channels for light ion beam propagation in the target development facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: 11th Symposium on Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.CH2251-7), 18-22 Nov. 1985
z:row.TitleTertiary: 11th Symposium on Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.CH2251-7)
z:row.Keyword: beam handling techniques|fusion reactor theory and design|ion beams
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma channels provide an attractive means of propagating light ions from ion diodes to inertial fusion targets. The advantages include pulse shaping of the ion pulse while it is in the channel, large standoff distances between the ions and targets, and relatively high density gases in the cavity that provide first-wall protection. The design and analysis of plasma channels for the light ion fusion target development facility discussed. Specific issues currently under study are channel formation with electrical discharges, the effect on the channels of the ion beams, energy losses by the ion beams while they are in the channels, interactions between channels, and the effects of externally applied magnetic fields on the channels
z:row.User2: light ion beam propagation; target development facility; inertial fusion targets; pulse shaping; first-wall protection; plasma channels; electrical discharges

z:row.TitlePrimary: NUMERICAL SIMULATION OF AN ICF TARGET EXPLOSION IN A STRATIFIED GAS ATMOSPHERE
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Seventh Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, Jun 15-19 1986
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR ENERGY -- Fusion Reactions|RADIOACTIVITY - Computer Simulation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Two-dimensional radiation hydrodynamic simulations of a light ion fusion target generated microfireball in a stratified gas atmosphere have been performed. The target location in a two region cavity was varied with the intent to reduce the overpressure on the diodes at the walls of a target chamber with a single cavity gas. Helium and nitrogen at 15 torr were used as the cavity gases; target explosions of 200 and 800 MJ were investigated. It was found that placing the target in a helium region surrounded by nitrogen could reduce the overpressure by a factor of 2 when compared with a single gas cavity of nitrogen. The surface heat flux was also reduced from a pure helium gas cavity.

z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS -- Fusion|FATIGUE OF MATERIALS|PLASMAS - Confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Target Development Facility (TDF) reaction chamber will be subjected to a mechanical shock from the cavity gas after each target ignition. This impulsive pressure produces transient stresses in the cylindrical shell wall which are characterized by an oscillatory response with decreasing amplitude. Such fluctuating stresses may fatigue the wall material and limit the useful lifetime of the chamber. Lifetime estimates have been determined and comparisons are made for chambers with different sizes, alloys and target yield.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: LIGHT ION FUSION TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY PRELIMINARY DESIGN

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility (TDF) is expected to test approximately ten targets per day having yields in the 50 to 800 MJ range. This large number of high yield microexplosions create design problems in the TDF that are not present in PBFA-I and PBFA-II. The TDF would be the first light ion facility where radioactivity in the target debris and induced in the facility itself constitute a biological hazard. A preliminary conceptual design for the TDF including a reaction chamber, biological shield, target diagnostics package and driver that addresses these and other problems is presented.

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Technology Inst, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In the HIBALL heavy ion beam fusion reactor design, the INPORT concept is used to protect the first surface of the reactor from damage by the high energy X-rays, ion debris and fast neutrons from the exploding target. Liquid Li//1//7Pb//8//3 flows through porous SiC tubes and wets outside of the tubes with a layer of Li//1//7Pb//8//3. This Li//1//7Pb//8//3 film is evaporated on each shot by the target X-rays and ion debris. The mechanisms that control the vapor pressure of the chamber are: gas radiation, Li//1//7Pb//8//3 evaporation from the INPORT tubes, and gas condensation back onto the INPORT tubes. From the beam stripping cross section for Bi**2** plus ions on Pb the gas pressure (evaluated at 0 degree C) inside the chamber must be at or below 10** minus **4 torr in order for the ion beam to reach the target and ignite it. The repetition rate is therefore determined by the time required to reestablish this pressure after a shot. Calculations are presented that indicate that this time is short enough to allow a 5 Hz repetition rate for a wide range of parameters.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: HIBALL HEAVY ION BEAM FUSION REACTOR; INPORT CONCEPT; BISMUTH IONS

z:row.TitlePrimary: LIMITS TO FUEL/COOLANT MIXING
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS, LIGHT WATER -- Core Meltdown|NUCLEAR FUELS - Melting
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: The vapor explosion process involves the mixing of fuel with coolant prior to the explosion. A number of analysts have identified limits to the amount of fuel/coolant mixing that could occur within the reactor vessel following a core melt accident. Past models are reviewed and a simplified approach is suggested to estimate the upper limit on the amount of fuel/coolant mixing possible. The approach uses concepts first advanced by Fauske in a different way. The results indicate that water depth is an important parameter as well as the mixing length scale D//m//i//x, and for large values of D//m//i//x the fuel mass mixed is limited to less than 7% of the core mass.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: VAPOR EXPLOSION PROCESS; FUEL/COOLANT MIXING

z:row.TitlePrimary: MF-FIRE - A MULTIFREQUENCY RADIATIVE TRANSFER HYDRODYNAMICS CODE
z:row.Keyword: HYDRODYNAMICS -- Computer Aided Analysis|HEAT TRANSFER - Radiation|COMPUTER PROGRAMS|GAS DYNAMICS|X-RAYS|NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: Inertial confinement fusion target explosions emit energy in the form of neutrons, X-rays and ionic debris. If the explosion is contained in a vessel filled with gas, the X-rays and ionic debris are stopped in the gas, forming a microfireball. The MF-FIRE code computes the attenuation of the target X-rays and debris in this gas and computes the radiation-hydrodynamic response of the microfireball. The MF-FIRE code simulates the response of a gas confined within a pressure vessel to the deposition of target X-rays and ions by solving the one-dimensional equations of radiation hydrodynamics in Lagrangian coordinates using standard finite difference methods. The radiative transfer is treated in the non-equilibrium multifrequency diffusion approximation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: COMPUTER CODE MF-FIRE

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radioactivity in the light ion fusion Target Development Facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Sixth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 3-7 March 1985
z:row.Keyword: dosimetry|fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor theory and design|radiation protection|shielding
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Radioactivity and biological dose calculations have been performed for the target chamber of the Target Development Facility (TDF). Two conventional shield designs are considered. One has the target chamber submerged 3 m from the surface of a borated water pool, the other has the chamber surrounded by approximately 250 cm of concrete. The first wall materials, Al-6061 and 2-1/4 Cr-1 Mo steel and the ion beam targets, one made from BeO2 and W and the other from CH2 and Au, are investigated. Shielding designs are presented that reduce the dose from each of these choices of shield, first wall and target material to acceptable levels

z:row.TitlePrimary: Analytic approach to the problem of nonlinear thermal conduction in laser-produced plasmas
z:row.Keyword: plasma production and heating by laser beam|plasma theory|plasma transport processes|thermal conductivity
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A nonlinear hyperbolic heat equation, established from Grad's `13-moments' method [Commun. Pure Appl. Math. 2, 331(1949)] is presented as an alternative to the classical heat diffusion equation for the treatment of thermal conduction in laser-produced plasmas. In the limiting case of a free streaming plasma, it is shown that this equation naturally generates the classical flux limiter, therefore absolving the recourse to empirical adjustments. The ensuing heat equation is a nonlinear wave equation with a front velocity determined by the thermal speed of electrons. When the collision term provides the dominant effect, the resulting equation is a nonlinear diffusion equation. Exact analytic solutions to these equations are obtained for an identical set of conditions and used to compare the speeds of thermal propagation and delimit the domain of applicability of the diffusion equation
z:row.User2: nonlinear thermal conduction; laser-produced plasmas; nonlinear hyperbolic heat equation; classical heat diffusion equation; free streaming plasma; heat equation; nonlinear wave equation; nonlinear diffusion equation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fatigue strength analysis of the Sandia Target Development Facility reaction chamber
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Sixth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 3-7 March 1985
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Target Development Facility (TDF) reaction chamber will be subjected to a mechanical shock from the cavity gas after each target ignition. This impulsive pressure produces transient stresses in the cylindrical shell wall which are characterized by an oscillatory response with decreasing amplitude. Such fluctuating stresses may fatigue the wall material and limit the useful lifetime of the chamber. Lifetime estimates have been determined and comparisons are made for chambers with different sizes, alloys and target yield
z:row.User2: fusion targets; Sandia Target Development Facility; reaction chamber; mechanical shock; target ignition; impulsive pressure; transient stresses; cylindrical shell wall; fatigue; lifetime

z:row.TitlePrimary: Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility preliminary design
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Sixth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 3-7 March 1985
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility (TDF) is expected to test approximately ten targets per day having yields in the 50 to 800 MJ range. This large number of high yield microexplosions creates design problems in the TDF that are not present in PBFA-I and PBFA-II. The TDF would be the first light ion facility where radioactivity in the target debris and induced in the facility itself constitute a biological hazard. It must have a first wall and a target diagnostics package that can survive repeated mechanical and thermal pulses from the target microexplosions. In addition, the repetition rate is much higher than for present day light ion beam drivers. A preliminary conceptual design for the TDF including a reaction chamber, biological shield, target diagnostics package and driver that addresses these and other problems is presented
z:row.User2: Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility; high yield microexplosions; design problems; target debris; first wall; target diagnostics package; thermal pulses; preliminary conceptual design; reaction chamber; biological shield

z:row.Abstract: The analysis of a steam generator tube rupture (SGTR) was performed using the best-estimator reactor system thermal-hydraulic computer code RETRAN-02. The Kewaunee nuclear power plant was used as the model. It is a two-loop Westinghouse pressurized water reactor designed for an initial power output of 1650 MW(t)

z:row.TitlePrimary: EQUILIBRIUM AND NON-EQUILIBRIUM MICROFIREBALL BEHAVIOUR IN LIGHT-ION FUSION SYSTEMS
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR ENERGY -- Fusion Reactions|NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR - Fusion|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: Light-ion fusion reactors and high-yield target testing facilities will have a gas-filled reaction vessel. The target microexplosion will create a microfireball in this gas. The behavior of this microfireball as it propagates and reflects from the reaction vessel wall is critical to the design of the vessel. The type of gas and the modelling assumptions used for analysis can significantly affect the prediction of this behavior. The effects of two-temperature and multifrequency radiative transfer models are investigated for nitrogen and argon gases. The isothermal sphere model and the target X-ray attenuation model for microfireball creation are compared. The computational results are related to the analytic strong-shock theory.

z:row.User2: TARGET MICROEXPLOSION; MICROFIRE BALL; RADIATION HYDRODYNAMICS MODELS

z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In a low-pressure severe core-melt accident sequence, the molten core will pour into the reactor cavity. To assess the possibility of a containment failure, it is important to know the extent of corium coolant mixing. Knowing this, the magnitude of the ensuing `steam spike' and the initial conditions for the molten corium/concrete interaction can then be concluded

z:row.TitlePrimary: NEUTRON ACTIVATION AND SHIELDING OF THE LIGHT ION FUSION TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, 5th, Apr 26-28 1983
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: It has been proposed to surround the target chamber of the Light Ion Fusion Target Development Facility with a water shield. Such a shield would effectively isolate the radioactive chamber from the environment while providing a medium in which to absorb energy imparted to the target chamber walls following the impact of the fireball. Radioactivity calculations are presented for five different wall materials. An investigation of the effects of a bubble screen upon the propagation of the water pressure wave is presented, along with some possible criteria for the design of a screen.

z:row.TitlePrimary: FIRE - A CODE FOR COMPUTING THE RESPONSE OF AN INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION CAVITY GAS TO A TARGET EXPLOSION
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: One of the methods that has been suggested for protecting the first wall of a commercial inertial confinement fusion reactor from the X-rays and ions emitted by an exploding target is to fill the cavity with a gas. The FIRE code described in this article simulates the interaction of the target X-rays and ions with the gas, and computes the response of the gas to a target explosion. The results computed by the FIRE code are useful for analyzing the thermal and mechanical response of a first wall that is protected with a cavity gas.

z:row.TitlePrimary: MIXERG - AN EQUATION OF STATE AND OPACITY COMPUTER CODE
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: To correctly predict the propagation of heat and shock waves through gases, one must have optical data, ionization states and internal energy densities for the gas. MIXERG is a computer code which has been written to provide low cost data for mixtures of up to five gases. The optical data consists of Rosseland and Planck mean opacities or mean free paths, in single group and in multigroup form.

z:row.TitlePrimary: LIGHT ION FUSION TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY PRE-CONCEPTUAL DESIGN

z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS|NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions|PLASMAS - Confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The light ion fusion target development facility will be used to test high yield ICF targets (50-200 MJ) at the rate of 10 shots per day. The 6 meter diameter cylindrical target chamber is designed as a first wall supported by a structural frame and is capable of withstanding 15,000 full yield shots over a 5 year lifetime. It is made from Al 6061, thus greatly reducing induced activity. The chamber is shielded by a water pool to allow easy access.

z:row.TitlePrimary: NUCLEAR ANALYSIS OF THE HEAVY-ION-BEAM-DRIVEN FUSION REACTOR HIBALL
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Fusion Engineering Program, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: A detailed three-dimensional Monte Carlo nuclear analysis is presented for the heavy-ion-beam-driven reactor HIBALL. Neutron target interactions leading to neutron multiplication, spectrum softening, and gamma production are included in the model. An 0. 66-m-thick blanket cooled by Pb//8//3Li//1//7 reduces the radiation damage in the HT-9 ferritic steel first wall to 2. 7 dpa/full power year, allowing it to last the whole life of the plant. The overall tritium breeding ratio and the overall energy multiplication are 1. 25 and 1. 27, respectively. The four reactor cavities in the HIBALL power plant yield a total thermal power of 10,200 Mw(thermal).
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: TARGET EXPLOSION GENERATED FIREBALLS IN THE NITROGEN FILLED TARGET CHAMBER OF THE LIGHT ION FUSION TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, 5th, Apr 26-28 1983
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: Molecular nitrogen is a possible choice for the target chamber gas in the light ion beam driven target development facility. The response of a nitrogen target chamber gas to fusion target explosions is considered. Targets with yields of 200 MJ, 400 MJ and 800 MJ are considered for a target chamber 3 m in radius and 6 m high which is filled with nitrogen gas at a density of 7. 07 multiplied by 10**1**7 molecules/cm**3. The soft x-rays and ions from the explosion of these targets are stopped in short distances in this gas and create a hot spherical fireball in the center of the target chamber. Heat fluxes and shock pressures on the target chamber first walls due to these fireballs are presented and nitrogen is shown to be an acceptable cavity gas from the point of view of first wall loading.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: TARGET CHAMBERS; NUCLEAR FIREBALLS

z:row.TitlePrimary: FIRST WALL MATERIALS SELECTION IN THE LIGHT ION BEAM TARGET DEVELOPMENT FACILITY
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proc of the Top Meet on the Technol of Fusion Energy, 5th, Apr 26-28 1983
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The choice of material for the first wall of the Light Ion Beam Target Development Facility is discussed. Materials considered are Al 6061, Al 5086, 304 stainless steel, HT-9 (ferritic steel), Ti-6Al-4V, Cu-Be C17200, and Cu-Be C17600. The thermal response, mechanical response and induced radioactivity in first walls made of each of these materials are calculated. Minimum thicknesses of these walls are determined and cost estimates are made for the material requirements for each wall. Finally Al 6061 is suggested as the best choice of first wall material.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A 1982 perspective on inertial confinement fusion education
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1982 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 6-10 June 1982
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Some opportunities exist for universities to be active in ICF-related research, although current emphasis is on physics problems and not fusion engineering. Positions are available for students with backgrounds in ICF disciplines. This is particularly true if one expands the viewpoint to include defense programs and magnetic fusion programs that utilize common physics and engineering backgrounds. However, there is little opportunity for non-US citizens in the ICF and defense areas due to security clearance restrictions. The prospect of teaching courses in ICF has been improved with the publication of a survey book covering this subject at the graduate level

z:row.TitlePrimary: A heavy ion beam fusion reactor concept, HIBALL
z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society 1982 Winter Meeting, 14-18 Nov. 1982
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The generation of electricity from inertially confined fusion reactors (ICFRs) has been studied for more than a decade. Early attention was given to laser-driven systems, but since the mid-1970s, another, more efficient form of driver has been studied. The use of very high energy (several GeV) heavy ion (>200 amu) beams to implode targets containing a deuterium-tritium (DT) mixture has several attractive features. The energy deposition of the particles is classical, the drivers are more efficient (~25% versus <5% for the realistic lasers), and the repetition rate is quite high. The authors describe a system, the Heavy Ion Beam and Lithium-Lead reactor (HIBALL), which uses all these advantages to generate electrical power

z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Second Topical Meeting on Fusion Reactor Materials, 9-12 Aug. 1981
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A method to protect the first metallic walls of ICF reactors from X-rays and target debris has been developed. The concept utilizes porous, flexible tubes of woven C or SiC fibers to contain liquid metals inside the vacuum chamber of an ICF system. These porous tubes allow for ablation and recondensation of liquid metal films. The tubes also moderate the neutron spectra and reduce the displacement and transmutation damage in metallic walls

z:row.Abstract: Materials response modelling is used to determine transient stresses in light ion beam ICF reactor first walls. It is shown that mechanical stress from the dynamic overpressure and thermal stress from the heat flux can be of comparable magnitudes. The maximum values of each and the time at which they occur in the material can be controlled somewhat by small percentages of sodium in the cavity gas. Such characteristics can guide materials selection

z:row.TitlePrimary: Time-dependent neutronics analysis for the HIBALL heavy ion beam fusion reactor
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|neutron transport theory|plasma confinement|plasma-wall interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Time-dependent neutronics analysis for the ferritic steel first wall of the HIBALL heavy ion beam fusion reactor conceptual design is presented. Neutron target interactions that lead to spectrum softening and neutron multiplication are accounted for. The time-of-flight (TOF) spread of neutrons within each energy group is considered. Neutron slowing-down in the INPORT first-wall protection system is found to significantly affect the time over which the damage occurs in the first wall. In the case of an unprotected wall, the time spread is determined primarily by the TOF spread. The INPORT concept is found to significantly reduce both average and peak instantaneous rates of displacements per atom, helium production, and energy deposition in the first wall

z:row.Abstract: Time-dependent neutronics analysis for the ferritic steel first wall of the HIBALL heavy ion beam fusion reactor conceptual design is presented. z:row.TitlePrimary: Time-dependent radiation damage to the first wall of a heavy ion beam fusion reactor with porous tube protection
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1981 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 7-11 June 1981
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In an inertial confinement fusion reactor the neutron source has a pulsed nature because of the very short burn time over which the fusion reactions occur. Consequently, high instantaneous displacement per atom (dpa) rates are present in an inertial confinement fusion reactor wall and structure. This can lead to significant changes in the microstructure of the first wall material and may result in higher recombination rates, which inhibits void growth and decreases swelling. In this work, the TDA time-dependent discrete ordinates code is used to perform time-dependent neutronics analysis of the HIBALL heavy ion beam (HIB) fusion reactor conceptual design
z:row.User2: radiation damage; first wall; heavy ion beam fusion reactor; porous tube protection; inertial confinement fusion reactor; neutron source; microstructure; neutronics analysis; HIBALL heavy ion beam

z:row.TitlePrimary: A coupled target-blanket neutronics and photonics analysis of a Li17Pb83 cooled heavy ion beam fusion reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1981 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (papers in summary form only received), 7-11 June 1981
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|lead alloys|liquid metals|lithium alloys
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A consistent neutronics and photonics analysis of an inertial confinement fusion reactor must account for neutron target interactions. Such interactions result in considerable softening of the spectrum of emerging neutrons, neutron multiplication, and gamma production. A consistent coupled target-blanket neutronics and photonics study is given for the HIBALL heavy ion beam (HIB) fusion reactor conceptual design. The effect of neglecting neutron target interactions on the different reactor parameters is investigated. The reactor design uses Li17Pb83 liquid-metal eutectic as the coolant/breeder. Among LiPb alloys, Li17Pb83 is chosen because it has the lowest melting point (500K) and the least reactivity with water. For further understanding of the neutronics and photonics characteristics of Li17Pb83, the effect of coolant thickness on the neutronic- and photonic-dependent parameters of the system is investigated
z:row.User2: coupled target-blanket neutronics; photonics analysis; Li17Pb83 cooled heavy ion beam fusion reactor; inertial confinement fusion reactor; emerging neutrons; neutron multiplication; gamma production; target-blanket neutronics; HIBALL heavy ion beam; Li17Pb83 liquid-metal eutectic; coolant/breeder

z:row.TitlePrimary: CAVITY GAS ANALYSIS FOR LIGHT-ION-BEAM FUSION REACTORS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: The criteria governing the choice of cavity gas for light-ion-beam fusion reactors have been investigated. Possible mechanisms of laser initiation of plasma discharge channels and the effects of cavity gas choice on one of the most promising mechanisms are discussed. The shock overpressure and the thermal heat flux experienced by the first wall are studied for a variety of cavity gases. Small amounts of alkali metal vapors are found to be useful in both limiting the thermal heat flux and initiating the plasma channels. A 50-Torr argon cavity gas with a 0. 2% sodium impurity has been found to allow both efficient laser channel initiation and first-wall survivability.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Low density cavity gas fireball dynamics in the light ion beam target development facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research, 26-29 Oct. 1981

z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: First wall survivability is a critical problem in the design of inertial confinement fusion reactor cavities. Previous studies have shown that in a light ion beam fusion reactor scenario, a bare, actively cooled ferritic steel first wall protected by a 50 Torr argon and sodium cavity gas will not experience excessively large stresses and could survive for the lifetime of the reactor. A target development facility to be completed in the late 1980s would have higher target yields and less gas protection than the LIFR. Recent calculations of wall stresses show that in a TDF, thermal stresses are much larger than mechanical stresses and that the maximum total stress is considerably larger than the yield stress for the ferritic steel. It is proposed that a graphite fabric liner be inserted on the inside edge of the cavity wall to reduce the total stresses in the wall to below the yield stress
z:row.User2: first wall survivability; light ion beam target development facility; inertial confinement fusion reactor; actively cooled ferritic steel first wall; wall stresses; thermal stresses; graphite fabric liner

z:row.TitlePrimary: High target gain to ICF reactor-a problem of repetition
z:row.TitleSecondary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research, 26-29 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The short-term goal of inertial confinement fusion (ICF) is high target gain, where the thermonuclear energy output from the target exceeds the driver energy input to the target by a factor of several hundred. Such a high gain, irrespective of the driver efficiency and how often the driver can be pulsed, will meet the military goals of the ICF program and will be a first step toward the realization of ICF as a viable electric power producer. Following the demonstration of high gain will come the task of repeating this feat at the rate of several times per second. It is here that the really difficult technology problems begin. None of the currently planned laser or ion beam drivers are designed for repetitive operation. (By this I mean at the rate of at least once per second). The CO2 gas laser and light ion systems have the potential for repetitive operation. However, they are currently rated in second and third place behind the Nd glass laser as the primary tool for studying target implosion
z:row.User2: ICF reactor; high target gain; thermonuclear energy output; driver energy input

z:row.TitlePrimary: INERTIAL CONFINEMENT FUSION REACTORS BASED ON THE GAS PROTECTION CONCEPT
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: Two inertial confinement fusion reactor designs based upon gas protection of the first wall from pellet debris and X-rays are reviewed. The first is the SOLASE laser fusion reactor design developed by the University of Wisconsin while the second is a light ion beam reactor cavity also designed at Wisconsin. In addition to describing these two reactors, the paper deals with the details of cavity gas dynamics and wall response for both cases. The dynamics of low pressure noble gas (xenon) for the laser fusion reactor and high pressure noble gas (argon) for the LIB fusion reactor are computed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: FUSION-FISSION HYBRID DESIGN WITH ANALYSIS OF DIRECT ENRICHMENT AND NON-PROLIFERATION FEATURES (THE SOLASE-H STUDY)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: In this paper, the overall fuel cycle and the concept of direct enrichment of LWR fuel in a hybrid fission-fusion reactor are discussed. The nuclear analysis and design of the blanket system, inertial confinement fusion performance requirements for hybrid applications, and the integrated SOLASE-H design are presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: HYBRID FUSION-FISSION

z:row.TitlePrimary: HEAT TRANSFER PHENOMENA IN GAS PROTECTED PARTICLE BEAM FUSION REACTOR CAVITIES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: The behavior of the fireball produced in particle beam fusion reactor cavities as the cavity gas near the target absorbs the X-rays and ionic debris emanating from the microexplosion is examined. Thermal response of the first wall to the radiative heat flux from the gas is examined parametrically. Criteria for the suitability of different cavity fill gases based on their ability to protect the first wall from excessive surface heating and ablation are discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: FIRST-WALL PROTECTION IN PARTICLE-BEAM FUSION REACTORS BY INERT CAVITY GASES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: Results of hydrodynamics calculations, including radiation diffusion, are reported for spherical blast waves that will occur in light-ion-beam fusion reactor cavities filled with a noble gas to protect the first wall. Calculations for argon show that the radiant heat pulse on a 4 m-radius wall is likely to be excessively large for reactor applications.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: PARTICLE-BEAM FUSION REACTOR; FIRST-WALL PROTECTION

z:row.TitlePrimary: MFP EM DASH A CODE FOR CALCULATING EQUATION OF STATE AND OPTICAL DATA FOR NOBLE GASES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: MFP is a code that computes ionization states and internal energies for gases. It also computes Rosseland and Planck averaged radiation mean free paths. These quantities are computed on a three-dimensional grid of gas density, gas temperature and radiation blackbody temperature.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: LASER FUSION HYBRIDS EM DASH TECHNICAL, ECONOMIC, AND PROLIFERATION CONSIDERATIONS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Dir in Energy Policy, A Compr Approach to Energy Resour Decis-Making, Proc of the Int Sci Forum on an Acceptable World Energy Future, 2nd, Nov 27-Dec 1 1978
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Technical Papers, Regional Technical Conference - Society of Plastics Engineers
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: A possible role for the fusion-fission hybrid in the context of an immediate nuclear future that may not include fuel reprocessing or the LMFBR has been examined. In such a role, the hybrid is used to irradiate fertile fuel assemblies, thereby simultaneously enriching the fuel to the proper fissile concentration and rendering it proliferation resistant by making the fuel highly radioactive.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Response of cavity gases to particle beam target explosions
z:row.TitleSecondary: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society 1979 Winter Meeting, 11-15 Nov. 1979
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor materials|nuclear engineering computing|plasma-beam interactions
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Noble gases at large pressures (≳50 Torr) may allow the formation of ionized channels for the transmission of particle beams while protecting the first wall of particle beam reactors from target debris and X-rays. In such a cavity gas, the pellet explosion forms a fireball which will propagate to the first wall. Subsequent interaction at the first wall results in mechanical and thermal stresses. A computer simulation code has been developed to study the evolution of these fireballs and obtain gas pressures and fluxes of radiant heat at the reactor first wall. These results are used to estimate the rate at which the cavity gas must be recirculated
z:row.User2: cavity gases; particle beam target explosions; ionized channels; computer simulation code; fireballs; gas pressures; fluxes of radiant heat; reactor first wall

z:row.TitlePrimary: COMPACT-ELECTRON-BEAM OR LIGHT-ION-BEAM FUSION REACTOR CAVITY DESIGN USING NON-SPHERICAL BLAST WAVES
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR REACTORS|ION BEAMS - Applications|ELECTRON BEAMS - Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: The application of inhomogeneous cavity gas densities and the nonspherical blast wave resulting from an explosion in this gas offers the potential to reduce the distance between the final diode and the target in a relativistic-electron-beam (REB) or light-ion beam (LIB) fusion reactor. It can also sharply reduce the overpressure experienced by the diode after the target explosion.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: LIGHT ION BEAM FUSION REACTOR; ELECTRON BEAM FUSION REACTOR; BLAST WAVES

z:row.Abstract: Examines the trade-offs between fuel and power production in fusion-fission hybrids so that optimum blanket designs can be identified. Attention will be focused on U/Pu systems: however, similar analysis can be performed for the Th/U cycle
z:row.User2: optimum blanket designs; U/Pu systems; trade offs; fusion fission hybrids

z:row.TitlePrimary: ENGINEERING PROBLEMS OF LASER-DRIVEN FUSION REACTORS
z:row.Keyword: LASERS|NUCLEAR REACTORS - Fusion|NUCLEAR ENGINEERING|NUCLEAR ENERGY - Thermonuclear Reactions
z:row.Abstract: The University of Wisconsin fusion reactor study group has completed a study of laser fusion reactor problems incorporated into a self-consistent reactor design, SOLASE. The purpose of the SOLASE study is to identify and quantitatively analyze the major technological features posed by laser fusion reactors, to assess the relative advantages and prospective problems, and to guide further research. The engineering problems examined in the SOLASE study include first wall design and protection, radiation damage and materials constraints, compatibility of first wall and pellet materials, placement and protection of the last optical elements, pellet injection requirements, tritium breeding and blanket design concepts, vacuum pumping requirements, heat removal and power cycle considerations, recirculating power requirements, and shielding and primary containment considerations. Other conceptual reactor designs have also been examined and critically compared.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: FIRST WALL DESIGN; LASER FUSION REACTORS

z:row.TitlePrimary: Blanket neutronics studies for the SOLASE-H hybrid reactor

z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The details of the neutronics calculations leading to the final blanket design are presented. Fuel assemblies based on the 232Th-233U cycle are enriched to 4% in the hybrid blanket and then the highly radioactive proliferation-resistant assemblies are placed directly into an LWR without intermediate reprocessing. The authors present an optimization study of different blankets to obtain a high 233U breeding ratio (UBR) subject to the constraints of a uniform fissile fuel concentration throughout the fuel assemblies and to determine a rotation scheme to achieve this goal
z:row.User2: neutronics calculations; 233U breeding ratio; fissile fuel concentration; SOLASE-H hybrid reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: Pellet X-ray spectra for laser fusion reactor designs
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The calculated X-ray energy contents, spectra and pulse lengths for a range of simple target designs that include deuterium-tritium fuel surrounded by mercury are given. The calculations start with a compressed pellet core at the time of ignition and the evolution of the burning pellet is followed by using a plasma hydrodynamic-thermonuclear burn-radiative transfer computer code. It is shown that the pellet-released radiation energy contents, spectra and pulse lengths depend upon pellet mass, density and material structure, and total yield

z:row.TitlePrimary: The SOLASE laser fusion reactor design and its technological implications
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design Concepts, 10-21 Oct. 1977
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactors|plasma confinement|plasma production and heating by laser beam
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A conceptual laser fusion reactor has been designed to elucidate the technological problems posed by inertial confinement fusion reactors. z:row.Abstract: One proposed method of protecting the first wall of laser fusion reactors is to introduce a low-density gas into the reactor cavity. z:row.Abstract: The combination of fusion with fission impacts the fusion reactor performance requirements and generally one is faced with a trade-off between relaxing the physics performance and lowering certain technology requirements. z:row.Abstract: The use of an inert gas at low pressure to protect the cavity walls of the Solase device from charged particles and soft X-rays is discussed. z:row.TitlePrimary: Improved treatment of electron thermal conduction in plasma hydrodynamics calculations
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor ignition|hydrodynamics|plasma production and heating by laser beam|plasma transport processes

z:row.Abstract: The mathematical models normally used to describe electron thermal conduction with a plasma hydrodynamics calculation are reviewed. An alternative formulation based on Grad's 13 moment method is presented. Numerical results for a laser-heated plasma show that the method provides physically plausible results

z:row.TitlePrimary: Laser fusion hydrodynamics calculations
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor ignition|plasma production and heating by laser beam
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Laser fusion hydrodynamics calculations include both the solution of the plasma hydrodynamics equations and transport equations for various nonthermal particles. The solution of the hydrodynamics equations is usually a combination of an explicit technique for the hyperbolic equation-of-motion and an implicit method for parabolic temperature equations. Transport equations are solved using fully implicit techniques to allow their time step to be as large as the time step used in the solution of the hydrodynamics equations. Multigroup flux-limited diffusion theory is often used to model the time-dependent transport problem. In this method, the diffusion coefficient is `adjusted' to provide a physically plausible result in the free streaming limit. Another method of solving the transport problem, time-dependent particle tracking, approximates the trajectory of the charged particles as straight lines, from creation to thermalization
z:row.User2: transport equations; hydrodynamics equations; parabolic temperature equations; fully implicit techniques; diffusion theory; free streaming limit; electron transport; distribution function; photon transport; multigroup theory; laser fusion; thermonuclear reaction products

z:row.TitlePrimary: Advanced fuels for inertial confinement fusion
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1977 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science. (Papers in summary form only received), 23-25 May 1977
z:row.TitleTertiary: 1977 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science. (Papers in summary form only received)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The two most basic parameters characterizing inertial confinement fuel pellet performance in the context of reactor applications are thermonuclear yield and pellet gain. Using a one fluid, two temperature Lagrangian plasma hydrodynamics code that also computes the rate of thermonuclear reaction and transports the charged particle reaction products through the thermal background plasma and transports radiation via a multi-frequency variable Eddington method the pellet yield and gain for advanced fuels (including DD, LiD, T and B11) are computed as a function of the above mentioned pellet parameters
z:row.User2: inertial confinement fusion; thermonuclear yield; pellet gain; Lagrangian plasma hydrodynamics code; thermonuclear reaction; Eddington method; DD; LiD; T; p11B
